title: China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs donates second batch of anti-epidemic equipment to Palestine
description: On June 24th, 2021, China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated a batch of epidemic supplies to Palestine. The Head of the Office of the People's Republic of China to the State of the Palestine and the Palestinian Minister of Health signed the handover certificate. The materials included 20 ventilators and 50,000 COVID-19 testing reagents. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs donates second batch of anti-epidemic equipment to Palestine

# Description
On June 24th, 2021, China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated a batch of epidemic supplies to Palestine. The Head of the Office of the People's Republic of China to the State of the Palestine and the Palestinian Minister of Health signed the handover certificate. The materials included 20 ventilators and 50,000 COVID-19 testing reagents. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical equipment (ventilators and COVID-19 testing reagents) for public health purposes

title: Chinese Government provides USD 1,000,000 for Emergency Food Assistance in Gaza Strip in June 2021
description: In June 2021, Chinese government provides USD 1,000,000 via United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East supporting emergency food assistance in Gaza Strip.

evidence: Emergency food assistance in Gaza Strip, humanitarian focus

title: Chinese government donates medical supplies as humanitarian aid to Yemen in January 2021
description: On January 17, 2021, the Chinese Government donated a batch of medical aid to hospitals and health centers in Hadramout, Yemen. The aid batch includes 14 items of medical equipment for admissions, emergency departments, and x-rays, in addition to beds for the obstetrics and gynecology departments, bed equipment, EKG machines, electric wheelchairs, and equipment for furnishing some hospitals. The Assistant Undersecretary of the Ministry of Public Health and Population, Dr. Hussein Al-Aush, and with him the Director General of the Health Office in Hadramout Coast, Dr. Muhammad Al-Jamahi, attended the handover ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese government donates medical supplies as humanitarian aid to Yemen in January 2021

# Description
On January 17, 2021, the Chinese Government donated a batch of medical aid to hospitals and health centers in Hadramout, Yemen. The aid batch includes 14 items of medical equipment for admissions, emergency departments, and x-rays, in addition to beds for the obstetrics and gynecology departments, bed equipment, EKG machines, electric wheelchairs, and equipment for furnishing some hospitals. The Assistant Undersecretary of the Ministry of Public Health and Population, Dr. Hussein Al-Aush, and with him the Director General of the Health Office in Hadramout Coast, Dr. Muhammad Al-Jamahi, attended the handover ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies and equipment for healthcare purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical equipment donation, healthcare sector focus, humanitarian aid context

title: Chinese government provides food aid to Zambia in November 2021
description: On November 4, 2021, the Chinese government provided food aid to Zambia. The donation included 3,099 tons of Chinese yellow corn. This food was donated to help citizens of Zambia overcome the aftermath of recent droughts. The maize will be distributed to vulnerable families by the Disaster Management and Mitigation Unit (DMMU) of Zambia. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Lusaka, Zambia. Dr. Situmbeko Musokotwane, the Minister of Finance and National Planning of Zambia, and Li Jie, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia, attended the ceremony and delivered speeches. The Permanent Secretary of the Office of the Vice President of Zambia, the Acting Coordinator of the Disaster Prevention and Mitigation Unit (DMMU) of Zambia, Counselor Liu Guoyu of the Chinese Embassy, and other representatives from China and Zambia also attended the ceremony.   Following the ceremony,  Minister Musokotuwa and Ambassador Li Jie jointly signed the handover certificate for this donation.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese government provides food aid to Zambia in November 2021

# Description
On November 4, 2021, the Chinese government provided food aid to Zambia. The donation included 3,099 tons of Chinese yellow corn. This food was donated to help citizens of Zambia overcome the aftermath of recent droughts. The maize will be distributed to vulnerable families by the Disaster Management and Mitigation Unit (DMMU) of Zambia. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Lusaka, Zambia. Dr. Situmbeko Musokotwane, the Minister of Finance and National Planning of Zambia, and Li Jie, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia, attended the ceremony and delivered speeches. The Permanent Secretary of the Office of the Vice President of Zambia, the Acting Coordinator of the Disaster Prevention and Mitigation Unit (DMMU) of Zambia, Counselor Liu Guoyu of the Chinese Embassy, and other representatives from China and Zambia also attended the ceremony.   Following the ceremony,  Minister Musokotuwa and Ambassador Li Jie jointly signed the handover certificate for this donation.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian food aid without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Food aid donation of 3,099 tons of yellow corn to address drought impacts, distributed to vulnerable families

title: Chinese Embassy provide 20,000 masks to University of Zambia in June 2021 (Linked to Project ID#98594)
description: On June 4, 2021, the Jilin Province of China and the Chinese Embassy jointly donated medical masks to the University of Zambia. The total number of masks provided was 50,000. The Jilin Province provided 30,000 masks while the Chinese Embassy provided 20,000 masks. These masks will be used to improve COVID-19 response efforts by the University of Zambia, the largest public university in the country. Masks will be distributed among students and faculty in the university. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Lusaka, Zambia. Li Jie, China’s Ambassador to Zambia, and Professor Luke Mumba, the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Zambia, attended the ceremony. Chinese and Zambian directors of the Confucius Institute at the University of Zambia also attended the ceremony.   Jilin Province's contribution to this donation is captured in Project ID#98594.
staff_comments: 1. Because the Chinese Embassy contributed 20,000 masks for this donation, AidData used the unit supply amount of face masks to estimate a monetary value of $6,680.00 USD.
combined_text:

justification: Project involves donation of medical masks for COVID-19 response, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Medical mask donation, COVID-19 response focus, healthcare sector

title: Chinese Government donates 100,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $1.8 million in August 2021
description: In 2021 and 2022, the Chinese Government donated approximately 600,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Zambia. The Chinese Government delivered 100,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Zambia on May 31, 2021. Then, on August 9, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 100,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines as well as 102,400 syringes to the Government of Zambia. Li Jie, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia, attended the vaccine handover ceremony and delivered a speech. The aid package was meant to help the Government of Zambia combat its third wave of COVID-19. The Chinese Government delivered an additional 400,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Zambia on January 24, 2022.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the May 2021 donation as $1.8 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 100,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $1.8 million in August 2021

# Description
In 2021 and 2022, the Chinese Government donated approximately 600,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Zambia. The Chinese Government delivered 100,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Zambia on May 31, 2021. Then, on August 9, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 100,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines as well as 102,400 syringes to the Government of Zambia. Li Jie, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia, attended the vaccine handover ceremony and delivered a speech. The aid package was meant to help the Government of Zambia combat its third wave of COVID-19. The Chinese Government delivered an additional 400,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Zambia on January 24, 2022.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of Covid-19 vaccines and syringes for public health purposes

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Zambia in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Zambia signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $334,384,000 ($289,956,000 in principal payments and $44,428,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Zambia. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Zambia secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Zambia in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Zambia signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $334,384,000 ($289,956,000 in principal payments and $44,428,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement is a financial arrangement without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt service suspension, financial terms, no specific project or environmental impact mentioned

title: Government of China provides medical equipment and medical team for COVID-19 Prevention to Zambia in January 2021
description: On January 7, 2021, the Government of China donated oxygen ventilators and other medical equipment to Zambia, in order to aid Zambia in COVID-19 prevention efforts. The supplies will be distributed to four main hospitals in Zambia. During the donation handover, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Jie stated that the government of China will send a medical team of 28 Chinese professionals to aid in Zambia's medical response to the COVID-19 pandemic. 20 of these professionals will be sent to Zambia's main hospital in Lusaka, 4 will be sent to Livingstone Hospital, and 4 will be sent to Ndola Hospital.  The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Government of China provides medical equipment and medical team for COVID-19 Prevention to Zambia in January 2021

# Description
On January 7, 2021, the Government of China donated oxygen ventilators and other medical equipment to Zambia, in order to aid Zambia in COVID-19 prevention efforts. The supplies will be distributed to four main hospitals in Zambia. During the donation handover, the Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Jie stated that the government of China will send a medical team of 28 Chinese professionals to aid in Zambia's medical response to the COVID-19 pandemic. 20 of these professionals will be sent to Zambia's main hospital in Lusaka, 4 will be sent to Livingstone Hospital, and 4 will be sent to Ndola Hospital.  The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare support and pandemic response without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Medical equipment donation, medical team deployment, COVID-19 prevention focus

title: China Electronics Technology Group Corporation donates 10 computers to University of Zambia in November 2021
description: On November 2, 2021, China Electronics Technology Group Corporation (CETC) donated 10 computers to the University of Zambia's Department of Computer Science. The computers were handed over by Wang Yao, CETC's managing director, and the purpose of this donation is to support the university's efforts to teach information and communication technology. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China Electronics Technology Group Corporation donates 10 computers to University of Zambia in November 2021

# Description
On November 2, 2021, China Electronics Technology Group Corporation (CETC) donated 10 computers to the University of Zambia's Department of Computer Science. The computers were handed over by Wang Yao, CETC's managing director, and the purpose of this donation is to support the university's efforts to teach information and communication technology. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project is a donation of computers for educational purposes with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 10 computers to university for ICT education, no energy-related components
